unnormalised: The formalization and digitization of the Indian economy have placed increasing emphasis on the comprehensive identification of businesses and taxpayers. This necessitates a deep understanding of the various identifiers employed by governmental and regulatory bodies. These identifiers serve not only for efficient tax administration but also for streamlined business operations and compliance monitoring. This article elucidates the primary taxation and business identifiers prevalent in India, highlighting their purpose and significance.

unnormalised: The Goods and Services Tax Identification Number (GSTIN) is a paramount identifier in the post-GST regime. It is a 15-digit alphanumeric code assigned to every registered business under the Goods and Services Tax (GST) framework. The structure is as follows: the first 2 digits represent the state code (e.g., "27" for Maharashtra), the next 10 digits are the PAN of the business, the 13th digit denotes the number of registrations within a state, and the last 2 digits are checksum characters. Businesses with aggregate turnover exceeding a prescribed threshold (currently INR 40 lakhs for goods and INR 20 lakhs for services, with exceptions for certain special category states) are mandated to obtain GSTIN. The GSTIN enables businesses to collect and remit GST, claim input tax credit, and conduct interstate transactions seamlessly. The GST portal provides a comprehensive database, allowing verification of any GSTIN, crucial for supply chain integrity. A hypothetical GSTIN might look like "27ABCDE1234F1Z5".
normalised: The Goods and Services Tax Identification Number (G-S-T-I-N) is a paramount identifier in the post-G-S-T regime. It is a fifteen-digit alphanumeric code assigned to every registered business under the Goods and Services Tax (G-S-T) framework. The structure is as follows: the first two digits represent the state code (e.g., "twenty seven" for Maharashtra), the next ten digits are the P-A-N of the business, the thirteenth digit denotes the number of registrations within a state, and the last two digits are checksum characters. Businesses with aggregate turnover exceeding a prescribed threshold (currently Indian Rupee forty lakh for goods and Indian Rupee twenty lakh for services, with exceptions for certain special category states) are mandated to obtain G-S-T-I-N. The G-S-T-I-N enables businesses to collect and remit G-S-T, claim input tax credit, and conduct interstate transactions seamlessly. The G-S-T portal provides a comprehensive database, allowing verification of any G-S-T-I-N, crucial for supply chain integrity. A hypothetical G-S-T-I-N might look like "twenty seven A-B-C-D-E one two three four F one Z five".

unnormalised: The Permanent Account Number (PAN) is a 10-character alphanumeric identifier issued by the Income Tax Department. It serves as the primary key for identifying taxpayers and tracking financial transactions. PAN is mandatory for various financial activities, including filing income tax returns, opening bank accounts, and making investments exceeding a specified limit. The PAN structure incorporates details such as the type of assessee (individual, company, etc.) and a randomly generated series. Failure to quote PAN in prescribed transactions attracts penalties. PAN is crucial for preventing tax evasion and ensuring transparency in financial dealings. For instance, "ABCDE1234F" is a valid PAN format.
normalised: The Permanent Account Number (P-A-N) is a ten-character alphanumeric identifier issued by the Income Tax Department. It serves as the primary key for identifying taxpayers and tracking financial transactions. P-A-N is mandatory for various financial activities, including filing income tax returns, opening bank accounts, and making investments exceeding a specified limit. The P-A-N structure incorporates details such as the type of assessee (individual, company, etc.) and a randomly generated series. Failure to quote P-A-N in prescribed transactions attracts penalties. P-A-N is crucial for preventing tax evasion and ensuring transparency in financial dealings. For instance, "A-B-C-D-E one two three four F" is a valid P-A-N format.

unnormalised: The Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number (TAN) is a 10-character alphanumeric identifier required for entities responsible for deducting or collecting tax at source (TDS/TCS). All entities making payments subject to TDS (e.g., salaries, contract payments, interest) must obtain TAN and quote it in all TDS returns and challans. TAN ensures that the TDS collected is accurately credited to the government account. Non-compliance attracts penalties. A typical TAN format might be "MUM123456A".
normalised: The Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number (T-A-N) is a ten-character alphanumeric identifier required for entities responsible for deducting or collecting tax at source (T-D-S slash T-C-S). All entities making payments subject to T-D-S (e.g., salaries, contract payments, interest) must obtain T-A-N and quote it in all T-D-S returns and challans. T-A-N ensures that the T-D-S collected is accurately credited to the government account. Non-compliance attracts penalties. A typical T-A-N format might be "M-U-M one two three four five six A".

unnormalised: The Corporate Identity Number (CIN) is a 21-digit alphanumeric code assigned to every company registered with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA). The CIN serves as a unique identifier for tracking companies and their filings with the MCA. The CIN provides details about the company's listing status, industry code, state of registration, year of incorporation, and registration number. For example, a CIN might be "U12345MH2000PLC123456". The CIN is vital for ensuring corporate governance and regulatory compliance. It helps in monitoring corporate activities, preventing fraud, and maintaining transparency in corporate affairs.
normalised: The Corporate Identity Number (C-I-N) is a twenty one-digit alphanumeric code assigned to every company registered with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (M-C-A). The C-I-N serves as a unique identifier for tracking companies and their filings with the M-C-A. The C-I-N provides details about the company's listing status, industry code, state of registration, year of incorporation, and registration number. For example, a C-I-N might be "U one two three four five M-H two thousand P-L-C one two three four five six". The C-I-N is vital for ensuring corporate governance and regulatory compliance. It helps in monitoring corporate activities, preventing fraud, and maintaining transparency in corporate affairs.

unnormalised: The Limited Liability Partnership Identification Number (LLPIN) is a 8-digit alphanumeric identifier assigned to every Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) registered with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA). The LLPIN serves as a unique identifier for tracking LLPs and their filings with the MCA. A typical LLPIN format looks like "AAB-1234". This identifier is crucial for regulatory oversight and ensuring compliance with the LLP Act.
normalised: The Limited Liability Partnership Identification Number (L-L-P-I-N) is an eight-digit alphanumeric identifier assigned to every Limited Liability Partnership (L-L-P) registered with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (M-C-A). The L-L-P-I-N serves as a unique identifier for tracking L-L-Ps and their filings with the M-C-A. A typical L-L-P-I-N format looks like "A-A-B hyphen one two three four". This identifier is crucial for regulatory oversight and ensuring compliance with the L-L-P Act.

unnormalised: Shop and Establishment Registration Number. Each state has its own Shops and Establishment Act, and businesses operating within a particular state must register under this act and obtain a registration number. This number varies in format from state to state and serves as proof of legal establishment and compliance with labor laws and regulations specific to that state. For example, a registration number in Karnataka might look like "S&E/BNG/123/2024".
